title: When do the clocks change: When to set them back in 2019 and forward in 2020
text:
We get an extra hour of sleep this weekend thanks to the time change (Picture: Acharaporn Kamornboonyarush)

In the UK, it’s been getting darker in the mornings and the days are growing shorter, which means it’s almost time for the clocks to change.

We last changed the clocks back in March when Daylight Saving Time started, but by next week the clocks will have gone back and sunrise and sunset will be one hour earlier, buying us a bit of extra sunlight in the mornings and evenings – or for a little while at least.

But when do the clocks change and when will we be putting them forwards again next year?

When do the clocks change?

Daylight saving time ends on Sunday October 27 in 2019, which means that the clocks are going back this weekend.

The time changes at 2am Greenwich Mean Time on October 27, meaning that 2am will then become 1am GMT instead – and yes, it also means that on Sunday morning you can hopefully enjoy an extra hour of sleep.

Most devices will adjust automatically (like smartphones often do do for time zone changes) for daylight saving time, so when you wake up on Sunday morning your phone should already show the correct time.

When do the clocks go forward again in 2020?

After this weekend, the clocks won’t change again until the spring.

The clocks will go forward one hour again on Sunday March 29 next year in 2020, when Daylight Savings begins again.
